For decades, the Hong Kong education system prioritized academic excellence, preparing students to excel in standardized tests and outperform their peers. Yet, there is increasing concern among parents and educators that such rigidity stifles critical thinking and self-expression. Today, many schools are introducing inquiry-based learning, project-based discussions, and collaborative group assignments in hopes of creating lifelong learners instead of mere test takers.

Take the story of Kenneth Lau, a secondary-school teacher in Kowloon who has witnessed these changes firsthand. Lau, a veteran teacher with over 15 years of experience, says, "When I first started teaching, everything revolved around exam preparation. But the more I worked with students, the more I realized that many of them were struggling to apply their knowledge outside the classroom." This realization prompted Lau to introduce voluntary debate clubs and student-run workshops aimed at improving problem-solving and communication skills. "The engagement I see now is night and day compared to a decade ago," Lau says proudly.
